author: Q U A S A R
title: MicroTask/Development Challenge
description: Catalyst has only 1 funding model and the time between proposals and receiving funds is not advantageous for developers of all skill levels.

assessments.note: The problem statement is unclear: why is it not advantageous for "developers of all skills". If it disadvantages low-skill developers, what is the benefit for the community to reward them? If the claim is that it disadvantages the skilled developers, what is the data from previous funds that backs up the claim? Why do mini-proposal need funding rather than being left to hobbyists?
assessments.reply: You cant fit all the answers in problem statement, but the answer is given in first sentence in the plan

assessments.note: The proposed work should help on-boarding new developers and expand Cardano's developer ecosystem.
This is an interesting trial that could help prove up a different funding model.

The funding through catalyst is a responsive system with build-in accountability and audit.  Allowing money to individual entities to fund proposals without community oversight can not be considered appropriate at this stage of Catalyst.
assessments.reply: First of all it will go trough community audit. Because proposals are created on the Ideascale if the proposer wishes so. We just get to help to accomplish the work and fund it before Ideascale maanges to relsea the funds. Gets things done faster

assessments.note: Having a different funding model that supports smaller chunks of work could help developers e.g. developers you want to create an MVP as prof of concept for a Catalyst proposal, or smaller pieces of work that need to be done as part of funded proposals. To fit the challenge (Developer Ecosystem) this mini-proposals would need to be "restricted" to development works, like solving small technical problems or contributing with code writing. The mini-proposals examples provided in the proposal do not fir this category so the proposal would benefit from specifying what classifies as mini-proposal within the context of this challenge

There are a lot of proposals on Catalyst that lacks the necessary team behind the proposal.  Microtasks can be the solution to those proposals and also encourage co-creation and collaboration. Completing microtasks will take less time, thus quicker funding and increasing developer adoption.
The proposal is to create templates for this mini-projects, and dedicate funds.  The plan doesn't explain why would voter be interested in reviewing the mini-proposals..
assessments.reply: These mini proposals are created for ideascale challenges

assessments.note: The proposers have demonstrated through working examples their capabilities of implementing their plan.

The plan is simple to implement but the methodology for selecting projects for funding is not clear. Catalyst follows a very rigorous peer review process. Without this step, it is not possible to assess the success of the initiative.

The proposal reads as if the proposers themselves would decide what is a mini-proposal and which ones get funded (and get paid to do this). Perhaps this is not the case, so the proposal would benefit from making it clear how mini-proposals are assessed and who decides on funding e.g. voting by the community ?
It's not clear where these mini-proposals would be posted ? The proposal seems to suggest that this would be on Project Catalyst, but then these need to follow the current timelines and processes, further clarity is required here. 
There is no clear implementation plan presented and the miro board is difficult to read, it's unlikely voters would spend time trying to decipher it. The proposal also doesn't address the risks of people abusing this system e.g. requesting funding for tasks that are part of an already funded Catalyst proposal.
The proposal would benefit from breaking the budget down further, why are we paying each member $900, to write guidelines, for specific training, management of proposals ? Overall $2700 ($900 x 3) to develop a proposal system that is based on the project Catalyst system, seems steep and is likely to deter voters.

The intentions are well placed, but the plan still needs some refinement.  When I first read the heading for your proposal, the first thing that popped up in my head was... Bigger proposals broken down and distributed among smaller groups of teams. Each team tackling a certain problem. I would love to see your proposal steer towards something like that. As you said under the heading - Defining success - 'We hope to design new ways to collaborate together.' If you can find a way to break down big proposals into microtasks, you have succeeded indeed. Maybe you should collaborate with Project Catalyst to assist with the voting and funding of microtasks. Keep up the good work and keep refining this idea.

The proposal doesn't provide the experience of the team members. It doesn't explain how the "product operation gets done effectively". It doesn't explain how the micro-proposals would be reviewed, and what ensures that the first mini proposal are operating within 3 months, nor why it actually takes 3 months if mini-proposals are targeting a $1k budget.
The proposal has detailed information regarding execution of their plan. There are minor concerns about long-term sustainability of the funding model.
Trialing different funding models in a small way like this is a useful project.

The proposal does not include what all mini-projects are going to be funded or the details regarding who will select the mini proposal for funding. Therefore it has no scope for assessing the suitability or the success criteria.

Setting a target of funding 10 proposals is the only tangible KPI. Things like "We will keep an eye on how many..." and "We look at how long it takes.." are not appropriate KPI's as the success metrics should to be defined a priori. The timeline presented is very vague. What do you mean by " at 3 months experimental mini-proposals will be operating" ? You will have mini-proposals funded ? At 6 months mark, "we are expediting the fund and project success process", how does the community measure progress against this ?
The roadmap and metrics are well defined, although the over-all plan still needs some fine tuning which in turn could change everything else.

solution: We will create additional treasury to fund mini-proposals, micro-work that will fund work throughout Project Catalyst.
